Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 1775 Newfoundland hurricane, also known as the Independence Hurricane, was a hurricane that struck the Thirteen Colonies and the Colony of Newfoundland in August and September, 1775, at the outset of the American War of Independence.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: It is believed to have killed at least 4,000 people,[1] making it one of the deadliest Atlantic hurricanes of all time.[2]

Total_Death_Per_Country.Death_with_annotation: On August 27, 1775, a hurricane hit the Outer Banks of North Carolina... At least 163 people were killed.[3]
A storm struck the eastern coast of Newfoundland on September 9, 1775... A total of 4,000 sailors, mostly from England and Ireland, were reported to have been drowned.[3]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: We had a violent hurricane... near 150 lives being lost at the Bar, and 15 in one neighborhood at Matamuskeet.
We had a violent hurricane... near 150 lives being lost at the Bar, and 15 in one neighborhood at Matamuskeet.
A storm struck the eastern coast of Newfoundland on September 9, 1775... A total of 4,000 sailors, mostly from England and Ireland, were reported to have been drowned.[3]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Insured_Da.Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_annotatio: The shocking accounts of damage done by the rains last week are numerous: Most of the mill-dams are broke, the corn laid almost level with the ground, and fodder destroyed; many ships and other vessels drove ashore and damaged, at Norfolk, Hampton, and York.

Newfoundland's fisheries 'received a very severe stroke from the violence of a storm of wind, which almost swept everything before it,' Commodore Governor Robert Duff wrote shortly after it struck. 'A considerable number of boats, with their crews, have been totally lost, several vessels wrecked on the shores,' he said.

Location_with_Annotation.North Carolina: A letter from New Bern, North Carolina, recounted, "We had a violent hurricane...which has done a vast deal of damage here, at the Bar, and at Matamuskeet, near 150 lives being lost at the Bar, and 15 in one neighborhood at Matamuskeet."
Location_with_Annotation.Virginia: The September 9, 1775, edition of The Virginia Gazette reported: "The shocking accounts of damage done by the rains last week are numerous: Most of the mill-dams are broke, the corn laid almost level with the ground, and fodder destroyed; many ships and other vessels drove ashore and damaged, at Norfolk, Hampton, and York."
Location_with_Annotation.Newfoundland: A storm struck the eastern coast of Newfoundland on September 9, 1775. Newfoundland's fisheries "received a very severe stroke from the violence of a storm of wind, which almost swept everything before it," Commodore Governor Robert Duff wrote shortly after it struck. "A considerable number of boats, with their crews, have been totally lost, several vessels wrecked on the shores," he said.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: The shocking accounts of damage done by the rains last week are numerous: Most of the mill-dams are broke, the corn laid almost level with the ground, and fodder destroyed; many ships and other vessels drove ashore and damaged, at Norfolk, Hampton, and York.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: Ocean levels rose to heights 'scarcely ever known before' and caused great devastation, Duff reported.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Landfall: On August 27, 1775, a hurricane hit the Outer Banks of North Carolina. It turned northeastward and left the state on September 2, bringing heavy wind and rain to southeastern Virginia.
